item.description: Hi! My name is Paul Larkin. I am currently a computing student and in my spare time I love participating in CTF’s, Kaggle competitions and reverse engineering malware. Amongst my other intrests, i also enjoy programing, where am beginning to explore the applications of machine learning and how it can be applied. Interests Malware Analysis Mobile and Web Application Security CTFs Machine Learning & AI

item.title: Learning Static Analysis For Windows Malware
item.description: In the following blog post, I am going walk through several of the steps I took learning static analysis from practical malware analysis book and samclass.info. Samples are from practical malware book by no starch press. I have however found and used different tools in relation to the book recommendations to speed up the process. Lab01-02.exe – Packed exe. To start of, I ran the sample through detect-it-easy which indicated that the sample is packed with UPX.

item.title: Pico CTF 2018
item.description: In this blog post, I want to share my thoughts on competing in a live CTF for the first time. The event was Pico CTF hosted online and created by Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) Cybersecurity and the world number two CTF team currently at the time of writing Plaid Parliament of Pwning (PPP). It is a very fun event with a series of different challenges, that on progression push you out your comfort zone just enough for you to have to research and learn new tools and techniques to capture the flag and earn points.

item.title: Leading a team for Magic CTF
item.description: Today, I am writing up a quick blog post on my thoughts and experience leading a cyber security CTF team and competing in Mid-Atlantic Gigabit Innovation Collaboratory (MAGIC) though my college. The event was participated in locally on registered sites with the competition end held online in the cloud accessed by SSH. All the challenges where unlocked and sitting on the server held in different level folders. Which wasn’t the same format as other capture the flag events, I have participated in where you unlock new challenges gradually after completing them.

item.title: Treatment for Diabetes APK Anlaysis
item.description: Sample hash: cf661506978f088f276a5a5bc4f0ea71101f99941840dd0864b2068ee2eb2271 This is the first sample I have reversed myself after completing Maddie Stones Android Reverse Engineering 101 course. Which was an excellent practical introduction and overview of reverse engineering mobile malware. It’s available at https://maddiestone.github.io/AndroidAppRE/ if your interested, i cant recommend it an enough. As for the sample, the APK itself was found around September time back in 2019 and was added to sk3ptre malware samples github repository in February 2020.
